section: 7.2 Integration as an Inverse Process of Differentiation
sub_headings: B. Examples and Non-Uniqueness of Integrals
notes: Integration is also referred to as anti-differentiation.
Every differentiable function has infinitely many antiderivatives, differing by a constant.
The constant of integration C allows for all possible original functions before differentiation.
Standard integrals can be directly memorized and used to solve complex integration problems.
tips_to_approach: Always check if a given function is a derivative of some known function.
Add the constant of integration C in every indefinite integral.
Practice recalling basic derivative and integral pairs for speedier problem-solving.
Understand how to use the notation and terms precisely to avoid confusion in exam-type questions.
